verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:1
verses.text: Book V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:2
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:3
verses.text: —Of the piety of the emperor Gratianus  How the Lord God is long suffering towards those who rage against him, and chastises those who abuse his patience, is plainly taught by the acts and by the fate of Valens.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:4
verses.text: For the loving Lord uses mercy and justice like weights and scales; whenever he sees any one by the greatness of his errors over-stepping the bounds of loving kindness, by just punishment He hinders him from being carried to further extremes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:5
verses.text: Now Gratianus, the son of Valentinianus, and nephew of Valens, acquired the whole Roman Empire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:6
verses.text: He had already assumed the sceptre of Europe on the death of his father, in whose life-time he had shared the throne.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 1:7
verses.text: On the death of Valens without issue he acquired in addition Asia, and the portions of Libya.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 2:2
verses.text: —Of the return of the bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 2:3
verses.text: The emperor at once gave plain indications of his adherence to true religion, and offered the first fruits of his kingdom to the Lord of all, by publishing an edict commanding the exiled shepherds to return, and to be restored to their flocks, and ordering the sacred buildings to be delivered to congregations adopting communion with Damasus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 2:4
verses.text: This Damasus, the successor of Liberius in the see of Rome, was a man of most praiseworthy life and by his own choice alike in word and deed a champion of Apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 2:5
verses.text: To put his edict in force Gratianus sent Sapor the general, a very famous character at that time, with orders to expel the preachers of the blasphemies of Arius like wild beasts from the sacred folds, and to effect the restoration of the excellent shepherds to God's flocks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 2:6
verses.text: In every instance this was effected without dispute except in Antioch, the Eastern capital, where a quarrel was kindled which I shall proceed to describe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:2
verses.text: —Of the dissension caused by Paulinus; of the innovation by Apollinarius of Laodicea, and of the philosophy of Meletius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:3
verses.text: It has been already related how the defenders of the apostolic doctrines were divided into two parties; how immediately after the conspiracy formed against the great Eustathius, one section, in abhorrence of the Arian abomination, assembled together by themselves with Paulinus for their bishop, while, after the ordination of Euzoius, the other party separated themselves from the impious with the excellent Meletius, underwent the perils previously described, and were guided by the wise instructions which Meletius gave them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:4
verses.text: Besides these Apollinarius of Laodicea constituted himself leader of a third party, and though he assumed a mask of piety, and appeared to defend apostolic doctrines, he was soon seen to be an open foe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:5
verses.text: About the divine nature he used unsound arguments, and originated the idea of certain degrees of dignities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:6
verses.text: He also had the hardihood to render the mystery of the incarnation imperfect and affirmed that the reasonable soul, which is entrusted with the guidance of the body, was deprived of the salvation effected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:7
verses.text: For according to his argument God the Word did not assume this soul, and so neither granted it His healing gift, nor gave it a portion of His dignity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:8
verses.text: Thus the earthly body is represented as worshipped by invisible powers, while the soul which is made in the image of God has remained below invested with the dishonour of sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:9
verses.text: Many more errors did he utter in his stumbling and blinded intelligence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:10
verses.text: At one time even he was ready to confess that of the Holy Virgin the flesh had been taken, at another time he represented it to have come down from heaven with God the Word, and yet again that He had been made flesh and took nothing from us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:11
verses.text: Other vain tales and trifles which I have thought it superfluous to repeat he mixed up with God's gospel promises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:12
verses.text: By arguments of this nature he not only filled his own friends with dangerous doctrine but even imparted it to some among ourselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:13
verses.text: As time went on, when they saw their own insignificance, and beheld the splendour of the Church, all except a few were gathered into the Church's communion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:14
verses.text: But they did not quite put away their former unsoundness, and with it infected many of the sound.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:15
verses.text: This was the origin of the growth in the Church of the doctrine of the one nature of the Flesh and of the Godhead, of the ascription to the Godhead of the Passion of the only begotten, and of other points which have bred differences among the laity and their priests.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:16
verses.text: But these belong to a later date.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:17
verses.text: At the time of which I am speaking, when Sapor the General had arrived and had exhibited the imperial edict, Paulinus affirmed that he sided with Damasus, and Apollinarius, concealing his unsoundness, did the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:18
verses.text: The divine Meletius, on the other hand, made no sign, and put up with their dispute.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:19
verses.text: Flavianus, of high fame for his wisdom, who was at that time still in the ranks of the presbyterate, at first said to Paulinus in the hearing of the officer "If, my dear friend, you accept communion with Damasus, point out to us clearly how the doctrines agree, for he though he owns one substance of the Trinity openly preaches three essences.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:20
verses.text: You on the contrary deny the Trinity of the essences.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:21
verses.text: Shew us then how these doctrines are in harmony, and receive the charge of the churches, as the edict enjoins".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:22
verses.text: After so silencing Paulinus by his arguments he turned to Apollinarius and said, "I am astonished, my friend, to find you waging such violent war against the truth, when all the while you know quite clearly how the admirable Damasus maintains our nature to have been taken in its perfection by God the Word; but you persist in saying the contrary, for you deprive our intelligence of its salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:23
verses.text: If these our charges against you be false, deny now the novelty that you have originated; embrace the teaching of Damasus, and receive the charge of the holy shrines".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:24
verses.text: Thus Flavianus in his great wisdom stopped their bold speech with his true reasoning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:25
verses.text: Meletius, who of all men was most meek, thus kindly and gently addressed Paulinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:26
verses.text: "The Lord of the sheep has put the care of these sheep in my hands: you have received the charge of the rest: our little ones are in communion with one another in the true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:27
verses.text: Therefore, my dear friend, let us join our flocks; let us have done with our dispute about the leading of them, and, feeding the sheep together, let us tend them in common.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:28
verses.text: If the chief seat is the cause of strife, that strife I will endeavour to put away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:29
verses.text: On the chief seat I will put the Holy Gospel; let us take our seats on each side of it; should I be the first to pass away, you, my friend, will hold the leadership of the flock alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:30
verses.text: Should this be your lot before it is mine, I in my turn, so far as I am able, will take care of the sheep".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:31
verses.text: So gently and kindly spoke the divine Meletius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:32
verses.text: Paulinus did not consent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:33
verses.text: The officer passed judgment on what had been said and gave the churches to the great Meletius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 3:34
verses.text: Paulinus still continued at the head of the sheep who had originally seceded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:2
verses.text: —Of Eusebius Bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:3
verses.text: Apollinarius after thus failing to get the government of the churches, continued, for the future, openly to preach his new fangled doctrine, and constituted himself leader of the heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:4
verses.text: He resided for the most part at Laodicea; but at Antioch he had already ordained Vitalius, a man of excellent character, brought up in the apostolic doctrines, but afterwards tainted with the heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:5
verses.text: Diodorus, whom I have already mentioned, who in the great storm had saved the ship of the church from sinking, had been appointed by the divine Meletius, bishop of Tarsus, and had received the charge of the Cilicians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:6
verses.text: The see of Apamea Meletius entrusted to John, a man of illustrious birth, more distinguished for his own high qualities than for those of his forefathers, for he was conspicuous alike for the beauty of his teaching and of his life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:7
verses.text: In the time of the tempest he piloted the assembly of his fellows in the faith supported by the worthy Stephanus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:8
verses.text: The latter was however translated by the divine Meletius to carry on another contest, for on the arrival of intelligence that Germanicia had been contaminated by the Eudoxian pest he was sent thither as a physician to ward off the disease, thoroughly trained as he had been in a complete heathen education as well as nurtured in the Divine doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:9
verses.text: He did not disappoint the expectations formed of him, for by the power of his spiritual instruction he turned the wolves into sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:10
verses.text: On the return of the great Eusebius from exile he ordained Acacius whose fame is great at Beroea, and at Hierapolis Theodotus, whose ascetic life is to this day in all men's mouths.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:11
verses.text: Eusebius was moreover appointed to the see of Chalcis, and Isidorus to our own city of Cyrus; both admirable men, conspicuous for their divine zeal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:12
verses.text: Meletius is also reported to have ordained to the pastorate of Edessa, where the godly Barses had already departed this life, Eulogius, the well known champion of apostolic doctrines, who had been sent to Antinone with Protogenes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:13
verses.text: Eulogius gave Protogenes, his companion in hard service, the charge of Carrae, a healing physician for a sick city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:14
verses.text: Lastly the divine Eusebius ordained Maris, Bishop of Doliche, a little city at that time infected with the Arian plague.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:15
verses.text: With the intention of enthroning this Maris, a right worthy man, illustrious for various virtues, in the episcopal chair, the great Eusebius came to Doliche.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:16
verses.text: As he was entering into the town a woman thoroughly infected with the Arian plague let fall a tile from the roof, which crushed in his head and so wounded him that not long after he departed to the better life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:17
verses.text: As he lay a-dying he charged the bystanders not to exact the slightest penalty from the woman who had done the deed, and bound them under oaths to obey him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:18
verses.text: Thus he imitated his own Lord, who of them that crucified Him said "Father forgive them for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:19
verses.text: Thus, too, he followed the example of Stephanus, his fellow slave, who, after the stones had stormed upon him, cried aloud, "Lord lay not this sin to their charge".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:20
verses.text: So died the great Eusebius after many and various struggles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:21
verses.text: He had escaped the barbarians in Thrace, but he did not escape the violence of impious heretics, and by their means won the martyr's crown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 4:22
verses.text: These events happened after the return of the bishops, and now Gratian learnt that Thrace was being laid waste by the barbarians who had burnt Valens, so he left Italy and proceeded to Pannonia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:2
verses.text: —Of the campaign of Theodosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:3
verses.text: Now at this time Theodosius, on account alike of the splendour of his ancestry, and of his own courage, was a man of high repute.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:4
verses.text: For this reason being from time to time stricken by the envy of his rivals, he was living in Spain, where he had been born and brought up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:5
verses.text: The emperor, being at a loss what measures to take, now that the barbarians, puffed up by their victory, both were and seemed well nigh invincible, formed the idea that a way out of his difficulties would be found in the appointment of Theodosius to the supreme command.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:6
verses.text: He therefore lost no time in sending for him from Spain, appointing him commander in chief and despatching him at the head of the assembled forces.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:7
verses.text: Defended by his faith Theodosius marched confidently forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:8
verses.text: On entering Thrace, and beholding the barbarians advancing to meet him, he drew up his troops in order of battle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:9
verses.text: The two lines met, and the enemy could not stand the attack and broke.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:10
verses.text: A rout ensued, the foe taking to flight and the conquerors pursuing at full speed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:11
verses.text: There was a great slaughter of the barbarians, for they were slain not only by Romans but even by one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:12
verses.text: After the greater number of them had thus fallen, and a few of those who had been able to escape pursuit had crossed the Danube, the great captain dispersed the troops which he commanded among the neighbouring towns, and forthwith rode at speed to this emperor Gratianus, himself the messenger of his own triumph.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:13
verses.text: Even to the emperor himself, astounded at the event, the tidings he carried seemed incredible, while others stung with envy gave out that he had run away and lost his army.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:14
verses.text: His only reply was to ask his gainsayers to send and ascertain the number of the barbarian dead, "For," said he, "even from their spoils it is easy to learn their number".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 5:15
verses.text: At these words the emperor gave way and sent officers to investigate and report on the battle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:2
verses.text: —Of the reign of Theodosius and of his dream.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:3
verses.text: The great general remained, and then saw a wonderful vision clearly shewn him by the very God of the universe himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:4
verses.text: In it he seemed to see the divine Meletius, chief of the church of the Antiochenes, investing him with an imperial robe, and covering his head with an imperial crown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:5
verses.text: The morning after the night in which he had seen the vision he told it to one of his intimate friends, who pointed out that the dream was plain and had nothing obscure or ambiguous about it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:6
verses.text: A few days at most had gone by when the commissioners sent to investigate the battle returned and reported that vast multitudes of the barbarians had been shot down.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:7
verses.text: Then the emperor was convinced that he had done right well in selecting Theodosius for the command, and appointed him emperor and gave him the sovereignty of the share of Valens.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:8
verses.text: Upon this Gratian departed for Italy and despatched Theodosius to the countries committed to his charge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:9
verses.text: No sooner had Theodosius assumed the imperial dignity than before everything else he gave heed to the harmony of the churches, and ordered the bishops of his own realm to repair with haste to Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:10
verses.text: That division of the empire was now the only region infected with the Arian plague, for the west had escaped the taint.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 6:11
verses.text: This was due to the fact that Constantine the eldest of Constantine's sons, and Constans the youngest, had preserved their father's faith in its integrity, and that Valentinian, emperor of the West, had also kept the true religion undefiled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:2
verses.text: —Of famous leaders of the Arian faction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:3
verses.text: The Eastern section of the empire had received the infection from many quarters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:4
verses.text: Arius, a presbyter of Alexandria in Egypt, there begat the blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:5
verses.text: Eusebius, Patrophilus, and Aetius of Palestine, Paulinus and Gregorius of Phoenicia, Theodotus of Laodicea and his successor Georgius, and after him Athanasius and Narcissus of Cilicia, had nurtured the seeds so foully sown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:6
verses.text: Eusebius and Theognis of Bithynia; Menophantus of Ephesus; Theodorus of Perinthus and Maris of Chalcedon, and some others of Thrace famous only for their vices, had for a long time gone on watering and tending the crop of tares.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:7
verses.text: These bad husbandmen were aided by the indifference of Constantius and the malignity of Valens.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:8
verses.text: For these reasons only the bishops of his own empire were summoned by the emperor to meet at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:9
verses.text: They arrived, being in all one hundred and fifty in number, and Theodosius forbade any one to tell him which was the great Meletius, for he wished the bishop to be recognized by his dream.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:10
verses.text: The whole company of the bishops entered the imperial palace, and then without any notice of all the rest, Theodosius ran up to the great Meletius, and, like a boy who loves his father, stood for a long space gazing on him with filial joy, then flung his arms around him, and covered eyes and lips and breast and head and the hand that had given him the crown, with kisses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:11
verses.text: Then he told him of his dream.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 7:12
verses.text: All the rest of the bishops were then courteously welcomed, and all were bidden to deliberate as became fathers on the subjects laid before them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:2
verses.text: —The council assembled at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:3
verses.text: At this time the recent feeder of the flock at Nazianzus was living at Constantinople, continually withstanding the blasphemies of the Arians, watering the holy people with the teaching of the Gospel, catching wanderers outside the flock and removing them from poisonous pasture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:4
verses.text: So that flock once small he made a great one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:5
verses.text: When the divine Meletius saw him, knowing as he did full well the object which the makers of the canon had before them when, with the view of preventing the possibility of ambitious efforts, they forbade the translation of bishops, he confirmed Gregory in the episcopate of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:6
verses.text: Shortly afterwards the divine Meletius passed away to the life that knows no pain, crowned by the praises of the funeral eloquence of all the great orators.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:7
verses.text: Timotheus, bishop of Alexandria, who had followed Peter, the successor of Athanasius in the patriarchate, ordained in place of the admirable Gregorius, Maximus—a cynic who had but recently suffered his cynic's hair to be shorn, and had been carried away by the flimsy rhetoric of Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:8
verses.text: But this absurdity was beyond the endurance of the assembled bishops—admirable men, and full of divine zeal and wisdom, such as Helladius, successor of the great Basil, Gregorius and Peter, brothers of Basil, and Amphilochius from Lycaonia, Optimus from Pisidia, Diodorus from Cilicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:9
verses.text: The council was also attended by Pelagius of Laodicaea, Eulogius of Edessa, Acacius, our own Isidorus, Cyril of Jerusalem, Gelasius of Caesarea in Palestine, who was renowned alike for lore and life and many other athletes of virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:10
verses.text: All these then whom I have named separated themselves from the Egyptians and celebrated divine service with the great Gregory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:11
verses.text: But he himself implored them, assembled as they were to promote harmony, to subordinate all question of wrong to an individual to the promotion of agreement with one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:12
verses.text: "For," said he, "I shall be released from many cares and once more lead the quiet life I hold so dear; while you, after your long and painful warfare, will obtain the longed for peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:13
verses.text: What can be more absurd than for men who have just escaped the weapons of their enemies to waste their own strength in wounding one another; by so doing we shall be a laughing stock to our opponents.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:14
verses.text: Find then some worthy man of sense, able to sustain heavy responsibilities and discharge them well, and make him bishop".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:15
verses.text: The excellent pastors moved by these counsels appointed as bishop of that mighty city a man of noble birth and distinguished for every kind of virtue as well as for the splendour of his ancestry, by name Nectarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:16
verses.text: Maximus, as having participated in the insanity of Apollinarius, they stripped of his episcopal rank and rejected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:17
verses.text: They next enacted canons concerning the good government of the church, and published a confirmation of the faith set forth at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:18
verses.text: Then they returned each to his own country.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:19
verses.text: Next summer the greater number of them assembled again in the same city, summoned once more by the needs of the church, and received a synodical letter from the bishops of the west inviting them to come to Rome, where a great synod was being assembled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:20
verses.text: They begged however to be excused from travelling thus far abroad; their doing so, they said, would be useless.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:21
verses.text: They wrote however both to point out the storm which had risen against the churches, and to hint at the carelessness with which the western bishops had treated it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 8:22
verses.text: They also included in their letter a summary of the apostolic doctrine, but the boldness and wisdom of their expressions will be more clearly shown by the letter itself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:2
verses.text: —Synodical letter from the council at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:3
verses.text: "To the right honourable lords our right reverend brethren and colleagues Damasus, Ambrosius, Britton, Valerianus, Ascholius, Anemius, Basilius and the rest of the holy bishops assembled in the great city of Rome, the holy synod of the orthodox bishops assembled at the great city of Constantinople, sends greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:4
verses.text: "To recount all the sufferings inflicted on us by the power of the Arians, and to attempt to give information to your reverences, as though you were not already well acquainted with them, might seem superfluous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:5
verses.text: For we do not suppose your piety to hold what is befalling us as of such secondary importance as that you stand in any need of information on matter's which cannot but evoke your sympathy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:6
verses.text: Nor indeed were the storms which beset us such as to escape notice from their insignificance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:7
verses.text: Our persecutions are but of yesterday.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:8
verses.text: The sound of them still rings in the ears alike of those who suffered them and of those whose love made the sufferers' pain their own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:9
verses.text: It was but a day or two ago, if I may so say, that some released from chains in foreign lands returned to their own churches through manifold afflictions; of others who had died in exile the relics were brought home; others again, even after their return from exile, found the passion of the heretics still at boiling heat, and, slain by them with stones as was the blessed Stephen, met with a sadder fate in their own than in a stranger's land.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:10
verses.text: Others, worn away with various cruelties, still bear in their bodies the scars of their wounds and the marks of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:11
verses.text: "Who could tell the tale of fines, of disfranchisements, of individual confiscations, of intrigues, of outrages, of prisons? In truth all kinds of tribulation were wrought out beyond number in us, perhaps because we were paying the penalty of sins, perhaps because the merciful God was trying us by means of the multitude of our sufferings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:12
verses.text: For these all thanks to God, who by means of such afflictions trained his servants and, according to the multitude of his mercies, brought us again to refreshment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:13
verses.text: We indeed needed long leisure, time, and toil to restore the church once more, that so, like physicians healing the body after long sickness and expelling its disease by gradual treatment, we might bring her back to her ancient health of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:14
verses.text: It is true that on the whole we seem to have been delivered from the violence of our persecutions and to be just now recovering the churches which have for a long time been the prey of the heretics.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:15
verses.text: But wolves are troublesome to us who, though they have been driven from the byre, yet harry the flocks up and down the glades, daring to hold rival assemblies, stirring seditions among the people, and shrinking from nothing which can do damage to the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:16
verses.text: "So, as we have already said, we needs must labour all the longer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:17
verses.text: Since however you showed your brotherly love to us by inviting us (as though we were your own members) by the letters of our most religious emperor to the synod which you are gathering by divine permission at Rome, to the end that since we alone were then condemned to suffer persecution, you should not now, when our emperors are at one with us as to true religion, reign apart from us, but that we, to use the apostle's phrase, should reign with you, our prayer was, if it were possible, all in company to leave our churches, and rather gratify our longing to see you than consult their needs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:18
verses.text: For who will give us wings as of a dove, and we will fly and be at rest? But this course seemed likely to leave the churches who were just recovering quite undefended, and the undertaking was to most of us impossible, for, in accordance with the letters sent a year ago from your holiness after the synod at Aquileia to the most pious emperor Theodosius, we had journeyed to Constantinople, equipped only for travelling so far as Constantinople, and bringing the consent of the bishops remaining in the provinces for this synod alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:19
verses.text: We had been in no expectation of any longer journey nor had heard a word about it before our arrival at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:20
verses.text: In addition to all this, and on account of the narrow limits of the appointed time which allowed of no preparation for a longer journey, nor of communicating with the bishops of our communion in the provinces and of obtaining their consent, the journey to Rome was for the majority impossible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:21
verses.text: We have therefore adopted the next best course open to us under the circumstances, both for the better administration of the church, and for manifesting our love towards you, by strongly urging our most venerated, and honoured colleagues and brother bishops Cyriacus, Eusebius and Priscianus, to consent to travel to you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:22
verses.text: "Through them we wish to make it plain that our disposition is all for peace with unity for its sole object, and that we are full of zeal for the right faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:23
verses.text: For we, whether we suffered persecutions, or afflictions, or the threats of emperors, or the cruelties of princes or any other trial at the hands of heretics, have undergone all for the sake of the evangelic faith, ratified by the three hundred and eighteen fathers at Nicaea in Bithynia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:24
verses.text: This is the faith which ought to be sufficient for you, for us, for all who wrest not the word of the true faith; for it is the ancient faith; it is the faith of our baptism; it is the faith that teaches us to believe in the name of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:25
verses.text: "According to this faith there is one Godhead, Power and Substance of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost; the dignity being equal, and the majesty being equal in three perfect essences and three perfect persons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:26
verses.text: Thus there is neither room for the heresy of Sabellius by the confusion of the essences or destruction of the individualities; thus the blasphemy of the Eunomians, of the Arians, and of the Pneumatomachi is nullified, which divides the substance, the nature and the godhead and superinduces on the uncreated consubstantial and co-eternal trinity a nature posterior, created and of a different substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:27
verses.text: We moreover preserve unperverted the doctrine of the incarnation of the Lord, holding the tradition that the dispensation of the flesh is neither soulless nor mindless nor imperfect; and knowing full well that God's Word was perfect before the ages, and became perfect man in the last days for our salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:28
verses.text: "Let this suffice for a summary of the doctrine which is fearlessly and frankly preached by us, and concerning which you will be able to be still further satisfied if you will deign to read the report of the synod of Antioch, and also that issued last year by the oecumenical council held at Constantinople, in which we have set forth our confession of the faith at greater length, and have appended an anathema against the heresies which innovators have recently inscribed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:29
verses.text: "Now as to the particular administration of individual churches, an ancient custom, as you know, has obtained, confirmed by the enactment of the holy fathers at Nicaea, that, in every province, the bishops of the province, and, with their consent, the neighbouring bishops with them, should perform ordinations as expediency may require.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:30
verses.text: In conforming with these customs note that other churches have been administered by us and the priests of the most famous churches publicly appointed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:31
verses.text: Accordingly over the new made (if the expression be allowable) church at Constantinople, which, as though from a lion's mouth, we have lately snatched by God's mercy from the blasphemy of the heretics, we have ordained bishop the right reverend and most religious Nectarius, in the presence of the oecumenical council, with common consent, before the most religious emperor Theodosius, and with the assent of all the clergy and of the whole city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:32
verses.text: And over the most ancient and truly apostolic church in Syria, where first the noble name of Christians was given them, the bishops of the province and of the eastern diocese have met together and canonically ordained bishop the right reverend and most religious Flavianus, with the consent of all the church, who as though with one voice joined in expressing their respect for him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:33
verses.text: This rightful ordination also received the sanction of the general council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:34
verses.text: Of the church at Jerusalem, mother of all the churches, we make known that the right reverend and most religious Cyril is bishop, who was some time ago canonically ordained by the bishops of the province, and has in several places fought a good fight against the Arians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:35
verses.text: We beseech your reverence to rejoice at what has thus been rightly and canonically settled by us, by the intervention of spiritual love and by the influence of the fear of the Lord, compelling the feelings of men, and making the edification of churches of more importance than individual grace or favour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:36
verses.text: Thus since among us there is agreement in the faith and Christian charity has been established, we shall cease to use the phrase condemned by the apostles, 'I am of Paul and I of Apollos and I of Cephas,' and all appearing as Christ's, who in us is not divided, by God's grace we will keep the body of the church unrent, and will boldly stand at the judgment seat of the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:37
verses.text: These things they wrote against the madness of Arius, Aetius, and Eunomius; and moreover against Sabellius, Photinus, Marcellus, Paul of Samosata, and Macedonius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 9:38
verses.text: Similarly they openly condemned the innovation of Apollinarius in the phrase, "And we preserve the doctrine of the incarnation of the Lord, holding the tradition that the dispensation of the flesh is neither soulless, nor mindless, nor imperfect".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:2
verses.text: —Synodical letter of Damasus bishop of Rome against Apollinarius and Timotheus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:3
verses.text: When the most praiseworthy Damasus had heard of the rise of this heresy, he proclaimed the condemnation not only of Apollinarius but also of Timotheus his follower.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:4
verses.text: The letter in which he made this known to the bishops of the Eastern empire I have thought it well to insert in my history.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:5
verses.text: Letter of Damasus bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:6
verses.text: "Most honourable sons: Inasmuch as your love renders to the apostolic see the reverence which is its due, accept the same in no niggard measure for yourselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:7
verses.text: For even though in the holy church in which the holy apostle sat, and taught us how it becomes us to manage the rudder which has been committed to us, we nevertheless confess ourselves to be unworthy of the honour, we yet on this very account strive by every means within our power if haply we may be able to achieve the glory of that blessedness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:8
verses.text: Know then that we have condemned Timotheus, the unhallowed, the disciple of Apollinarius the heretic, together with his impious doctrine, and are confident that for the future his remains will have no weight whatever.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:9
verses.text: But if that old serpent, though smitten once and again, still revives to his own destruction, who though he exists without the church never ceases from the attempt by his deadly venom to overthrow certain unfaithful men, do you avoid it as you would a pest, mindful ever of the apostolic faith—that, I mean, which was set out in writing by the Fathers at Nicaea; do you remain on steady ground, firm and unmoved in the faith, and henceforward suffer neither your clergy nor laity to listen to vain words and futile questions, for we have already given a form, that he who professes himself a Christian may keep it, the form delivered by the Apostles, as says St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:10
verses.text: Paul, 'if any one preach to you another gospel than that you have received let him be Anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:11
verses.text: ' For Christ the Son of God, our Lord, gave by his own passion abundant salvation to the race of men, that he might free from all sin the whole man involved in sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:12
verses.text: If any one speaks of Christ as having had less of manhood or of Godhead, he is full of devils' spirits, and proclaims himself a child of hell.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:13
verses.text: "Why then do you again ask me for the condemnation of Timotheus? Here, by the judgment of the apostolic see, in the presence of Peter, bishop of Alexandria, he was condemned, together with his teacher, Apollinarius, who will also in the day of judgment undergo due punishment and torment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:14
verses.text: But if he succeeds in persuading some less stable men, as though having some hope, after by his confession changing the true hope which is in Christ, with him shall likewise perish whoever of set purpose withstands the order of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:15
verses.text: May God keep you sound, most honoured sons".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 10:16
verses.text: The bishops assembled in great Rome also wrote other things against other heresies which I have thought it necessary to insert in my history.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:2
verses.text: —A confession of the Catholic faith which Pope Damasus sent to Bishop Paulinus in Macedonia when he was at Thessalonica.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:3
verses.text: After the Council of Nicaea there sprung up this error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:4
verses.text: Certain men ventured with profane mouths to say that the Holy Spirit is made through the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:5
verses.text: We therefore anathematize those who do not with all freedom preach that the Holy Spirit is of one and the same substance and power with the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:6
verses.text: In like manner we anathematize them that follow the error of Sabellius and say that the Father and the Son are the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:7
verses.text: We anathematize Arius and Eunomius who with equal impiety, though with differences of phrase, maintain the Son and the Holy Spirit to be a creature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:8
verses.text: We anathematize the Macedonians who, produced from the root of Arius, have changed the name but not the impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:9
verses.text: We anathematize Photinus who, renewing the heresy of Ebion, confessed that our Lord Jesus Christ was only of Mary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:10
verses.text: We anathematize them that maintain that there are two sons—one before the ages and another after the assumption of the flesh from Mary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:11
verses.text: We anathematize also all who maintain that the Word of God moved in human flesh instead of a reasonable soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:12
verses.text: For this Word of God Himself was not in His own body instead of a reasonable and intellectual soul, but assumed and saved our soul, both reasonable and intellectual, without sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:13
verses.text: We anathematize also them that say that the Word of God is separated from the Father by extension and contraction, and blasphemously affirm that He is without essential being or is destined to die.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:14
verses.text: Them that have gone from churches to other churches we so far hold alien from our communion till they shall have returned to those cities in which they were first ordained.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:15
verses.text: If any one, when another has gone from place to place, has been ordained in his stead, let him who abandoned his own city be held deprived of his episcopal rank until such time as his successor shall rest in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:16
verses.text: If any one denies that the Father is eternal and the Son eternal and the Holy Ghost eternal, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:17
verses.text: If any one denies that the Son was begotten of the Father, that is of His divine substance, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:18
verses.text: If any one denies that the Son of God is very God, omnipotent and omniscient, and equal to the Father, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:19
verses.text: If any one says that the Son of God, living in the flesh when he was on the earth, was not in heaven and with the Father, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:20
verses.text: If any one says that in the Passion of the Cross the Son of God sustained its pain by Godhead, and not by reasonable soul and flesh which He had assumed in the form of a servant, as saith the Holy Scripture, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:21
verses.text: If any one denies that the Word of God suffered in the flesh and tasted death in the flesh, and was the first-born of the dead, as the Son is life and giver of life, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:22
verses.text: If any one deny that He sits on the right hand of the Father in the flesh which He assumed, and in which He shall come to judge quick and dead, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:23
verses.text: If any one deny that the Holy Spirit is truly and absolutely of the Father, and that the Son is of the divine substance and very God of God, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:24
verses.text: If any one deny that the Holy Spirit is omnipotent, omniscient, and omnipresent, as also the Son of the Father, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:25
verses.text: If any one say that the Holy Spirit is a created being or was made through the Son, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:26
verses.text: If any one deny that the Father made all things visible and invisible, through the Son who was made Flesh, and the Holy Spirit, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:27
verses.text: If any one deny one Godhead and power, one sovereignty and glory, one lordship, one kingdom, will and truth of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:28
verses.text: If any one deny three very persons of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost, living for ever, containing all things visible and invisible, omnipotent, judging all things, giving life to all things, creating all things and preserving all things, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:29
verses.text: If any one denies that the Holy Ghost is to be worshipped by all creation, as the Son, and as the Father, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:30
verses.text: If any one shall think aright about the Father and the Son but does not hold aright about the Holy Ghost, anathema, because he is a heretic, for all the heretics who do not think aright about God the Son and about the Holy Ghost are convicted of being involved in the unbelief of the Jews and the heathen; and if any one shall divide Godhead, saying that the Father is God apart and the Son God, and the Holy Ghost God, and should persist that they are called Gods and not God, on account of the one Godhead and sovereignty which we believe and know there to be of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost—one God in three essences,—or withdrawing the Son and the Holy Ghost so as to suggest that the Father alone is called God and believed in as one God, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:31
verses.text: For the name of gods has been bestowed by God upon angels and all saints, but of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost on account of their one and equal Godhead, not the names of "gods" but the name of "our God" is predicated and proclaimed, that we may believe that we are baptized in Father and Son and Holy Ghost and not in the names of archangels or angels, like the heretics or the Jews or foolish heathen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:32
verses.text: This is the salvation of the Christians, that believing in the Trinity, that is in the Father and the Son and the Holy Ghost, and being baptized into the same one Godhead and power and divinity and substance, in Him we may trust.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 11:33
verses.text: These events happened during the life of Gratianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 12:2
verses.text: —Of the death of Gratianus and the sovereignty of Maximus  Gratianus in the midst of his successes in war and wise and prudent government ended his life by conspiracy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 12:3
verses.text: He left no sons to inherit the empire, and a brother of the same name as their father, Valentinianus, who was quite a youth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 12:4
verses.text: So Maximus, in contempt of the youth of Valentinianus, seized the throne of the West.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:2
verses.text: —Of Justina, the wife of Valentinianus, and of her plot against Ambrosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:3
verses.text: At this time Justina, wife of Valentinianus the great, and mother of the young prince, made known to her son the seeds of the Arian teaching which she had long ago received.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:4
verses.text: Well knowing the warmth of her consort's faith she had endeavoured to conceal her sentiments during the whole of his life, but perceiving that her son's character was gentle and docile, she took courage to bring her deceitful doctrine forward.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:5
verses.text: The lad supposed his mother's counsels to be wise and beneficial, for nature so disposed the bait that he could not see the deadly hook below.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:6
verses.text: He first communicated on the subject with Ambrosius, under the impression that, if he could persuade the bishop, he would be able without difficulty to prevail over the rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:7
verses.text: Ambrosius, however, strove to remind him of his father's piety, and exhorted him to keep inviolate the heritage which he had received.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:8
verses.text: He explained to him also how one doctrine differed from the other, how the one is in agreement with the teaching of the Lord and with the teaching of his apostles, while the other is totally opposed to it and at war with the code of the laws of the spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:9
verses.text: The young man, as young men will, spurred on moreover by a mother herself the victim of deceit, not only did not assent to the arguments adduced, but lost his temper, and, in a passion, was for surrounding the approaches to the church with companies of legionaries and targeteers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:10
verses.text: When, however, he learnt that this illustrious champion was not in the least alarmed at his proceedings, for Ambrosius treated them all like the ghosts and hobgoblins with which some men try to frighten babies, he was exceedingly angry and publicly ordered him to depart from the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:11
verses.text: "I shall not," said Ambrosius, "do so willingly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:12
verses.text: I will not yield the sheepfold to the wolves nor betray God's temple to blasphemers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:13
verses.text: If you wish to slay me drive your sword or your spear into me here within.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 13:14
verses.text: I shall welcome such a death".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 14:2
verses.text: —Of the information given by Maximus the tyrant to Valentinianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 14:3
verses.text: After a considerable time Maximus was informed of the attacks which were being made upon the loud-voiced herald of the truth, and he sent dispatches to Valentinianus charging him to put a stop to his war against true religion and exhorting him not to abandon his father's faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 14:4
verses.text: In the event of his advice being disregarded he further threatened war, and confirmed what he wrote by what he did, for he mustered his forces and marched for Milan where Valentinianus was then residing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 14:5
verses.text: When the latter heard of his approach he fled into Illyricum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 14:6
verses.text: He had learnt by experience what good he had got by following his mother's advice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:2
verses.text: —Of the Letter written by the Emperor Theodosius concerning the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:3
verses.text: When the illustrious emperor Theodosius had heard of the emperor's doings and what the tyrant Maximus had written to him he wrote to the fugitive youth to this effect: You must not be astonished if to you has come panic and to your enemy victory; for you have been fighting against piety, and he on its side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:4
verses.text: You abandoned it, and are running away naked.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:5
verses.text: He in its panoply is getting the mastery of you stripped bare of it, for He who hath given us the law of true religion is ever on its side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:6
verses.text: So wrote Theodosius when he was yet afar off; but when he had heard of Valentinian's flight, and had come to his aid, and saw him an exile, taking refuge in his own empire, his first thought was to give succour to his soul, drive out the intruding pestilence of impiety, and win him back to the true religion of his fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:7
verses.text: Then he bade him be of good cheer and marched against the tyrant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:8
verses.text: He gave the lad his empire again without loss of blood and slew Maximus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 15:9
verses.text: For he felt that he should be guilty of wrong and should violate the terms of his treaty with Gratianus were he not to take vengeance on those who had caused his ally's death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:2
verses.text: —Of Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:3
verses.text: On the emperor's return the admirable Amphilochius, whom I have often mentioned, came to beg that the Arian congregations might be expelled from the cities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:4
verses.text: The emperor thought the petition too severe, and refused it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:5
verses.text: The very wise Amphilochius at the moment was silent, for he had hit upon a memorable device.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:6
verses.text: The next time he entered the Palace and beheld standing at the emperor's side his son Arcadius, who had lately been appointed emperor, he saluted Theodosius as was his wont, but did no honour to Arcadius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:7
verses.text: The emperor, thinking that this neglect was due to forgetfulness, commanded Amphilochius to approach and to salute his son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:8
verses.text: "Sir," said he, "the honour which I have paid you is enough".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:9
verses.text: Theodosius was indignant at the discourtesy, and said, "Dishonour done to my son is a rudeness to myself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:10
verses.text: Then, and not till then, the very wise Amphilochius disclosed the object of his conduct, and said with a loud voice, "You see, sir, that you do not brook dishonour done your son, and are bitterly angry with those who are rude to him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:11
verses.text: Believe then that the God of all the world abominates them that blaspheme the Only begotten Son, and hates them as ungrateful to their Saviour and Benefactor".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:12
verses.text: Then the emperor understood the bishop's drift, and admired both what he had done and what he had said.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:13
verses.text: Without further delay he put out an edict forbidding the congregations of heretics.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:14
verses.text: But to escape all the snares of the common enemy of mankind is no easy task.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:15
verses.text: Often it happens that one who has kept clear of lascivious passion is fixed fast in the toils of avarice; and if he prove superior to greed there on the other side is the pitfall of envy, and even if he leap safe over this he will find a net of passion waiting for him on the other side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:16
verses.text: Other innumerable stumbling blocks the enemy sets in men's paths, trying to catch them to their ruin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:17
verses.text: Then he has at his disposal the bodily passions to help the wiles which he lays against the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:18
verses.text: The mind alone, if it keep awake, gets the better of him, frustrating the assault of his devices by its inclination to what is Divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:19
verses.text: Now, since this admirable emperor had his share of human nature, and was not free from its emotions, his righteous anger passed the bounds of moderation, and caused the perpetration of a savage and lawless deed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 16:20
verses.text: I must tell this story for the sake of those into whose hands it will fall; it does not, indeed, only involve blame of the admirable emperor, but so redounds to his credit as to deserve to be remembered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:2
verses.text: —Of the massacre of Thessalonica; the boldness of Bishop Ambrosius, and the piety of the Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:3
verses.text: Thessalonica is a large and very populous city, belonging to Macedonia, but the capital of Thessaly and Achaia, as well as of many other provinces which are governed by the prefect of Illyricum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:4
verses.text: Here arose a great sedition, and several of the magistrates were stoned and violently treated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:5
verses.text: The emperor was fired with anger when he heard the news, and unable to endure the rush of his passion, did not even check its onset by the curb of reason, but allowed his rage to be the minister of his vengeance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:6
verses.text: When the imperial passion had received its authority, as though itself an independent prince, it broke the bonds and yoke of reason, unsheathed swords of injustice right and left without distinction, and slew innocent and guilty together.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:7
verses.text: No trial preceded the sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:8
verses.text: No condemnation was passed on the perpetrators of the crimes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:9
verses.text: Multitudes were mowed down like ears of corn in harvest-tide.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:10
verses.text: It is said that seven thousand perished.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:11
verses.text: News of this lamentable calamity reached Ambrosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:12
verses.text: The emperor on his arrival at Milan wished according to custom to enter the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:13
verses.text: Ambrosius met him outside the outer porch and forbade him to step over the sacred threshold.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:14
verses.text: "You seem, sir, not to know," said he, "the magnitude of the bloody deed that has been done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:15
verses.text: Your rage has subsided, but your reason has not yet recognised the character of the deed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:16
verses.text: Peradventure your Imperial power prevents your recognising the sin, and power stands in the light of reason.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:17
verses.text: We must however know how our nature passes away and is subject to death; we must know the ancestral dust from which we sprang, and to which we are swiftly returning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:18
verses.text: We must not because we are dazzled by the sheen of the purple fail to see the weakness of the body that it robes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:19
verses.text: You are a sovereign, Sir, of men of like nature with your own, and who are in truth your fellow slaves; for there is one Lord and Sovereign of mankind, Creator of the Universe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:20
verses.text: With what eyes then will you look on the temple of our common Lord—with what feet will you tread that holy threshold, how will you stretch forth your hands still dripping with the blood of unjust slaughter? How in such hands will you receive the all holy Body of the Lord? How will you who in your rage unrighteously poured forth so much blood lift to your lips the precious Blood? Begone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:21
verses.text: Attempt not to add another crime to that which you have committed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:22
verses.text: Submit to the restriction to which the God the Lord of all agrees that you be sentenced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:23
verses.text: He will be your physician, He will give you health".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:24
verses.text: Educated as he had been in the sacred oracles, Theodosius knew clearly what belonged to priests and what to emperors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:25
verses.text: He therefore bowed to the rebuke of Ambrose, and retired sighing and weeping to the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:26
verses.text: After a considerable time, when eight months had passed away, the festival of our Saviour's birth came round and the emperor sat in his palace shedding a storm of tears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:27
verses.text: Now Rufinus, at that time controller of the household, and, from his familiarity with his imperial master, able to use great freedom of speech, approached and asked him why he wept.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:28
verses.text: With a bitter groan and yet more abundant weeping "You are trifling, Rufinus," said the emperor, "because you do not feel my troubles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:29
verses.text: I am groaning and lamenting at the thought of my own calamity; for menials and for beggars the way into the church lies open; they can go in without fear, and put up their petitions to their own Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:30
verses.text: I dare not set my foot there, and besides this for me the door of heaven is shut, for I remember the voice of the Lord which plainly says, 'Whatsoever ye bind on earth shall have been bound in heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:31
verses.text: '"  Rufinus replied "With your permission I will hasten to the bishop, and by my entreaties induce him to remit your penalty".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:32
verses.text: "He will not yield" said the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:33
verses.text: "I know the justice of the sentence passed by Ambrose, nor will he ever be moved by respect for my imperial power to transgress the law of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:34
verses.text: Rufinus urged his suit again and again, promising to win over Ambrosius; and at last the emperor commanded him to go with all despatch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:35
verses.text: Then, the victim of false hopes, Theodosius, in reliance on the promises of Rufinus, followed in person, himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:36
verses.text: No sooner did the divine Ambrose perceive Rufinus than he exclaimed, "Rufinus, your impudence matches a dog's, for you were the adviser of this terrible slaughter; you have wiped shame from your brow, and guilty as you are of this mad outrage on the image of God you stand here fearless, without a blush".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:37
verses.text: Then Rufinus began to beg and pray, and announced the speedy approach of the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:38
verses.text: Fired with divine zeal the holy Ambrosius exclaimed "Rufinus, I tell you beforehand; I shall prevent him from crossing the sacred threshold.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:39
verses.text: If he is for changing his sovereign power into that of a tyrant I too will gladly submit to a violent death".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:40
verses.text: On this Rufinus sent a messenger to inform the emperor in what mind the archbishop was, and exhorted him to remain within the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:41
verses.text: Theodosius had already reached the middle of the forum when he received the message.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:42
verses.text: "I will go," said he, "and accept the disgrace I deserve".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:43
verses.text: He advanced to the sacred precincts but did not enter the holy building.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:44
verses.text: The archbishop was seated in the house of salutation and there the emperor approached him and besought that his bonds might be loosed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:45
verses.text: "Your coming" said Ambrose "is the coming of a tyrant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:46
verses.text: You are raging against God; you are trampling on his laws".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:47
verses.text: "No," said Theodosius, "I do not attack laws laid down, I do not seek wrongfully to cross the sacred threshold; but I ask you to loose my bond, to take into account the mercy of our common Lord, and not to shut against me a door which our master has opened for all them that repent".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:48
verses.text: The archbishop replied "What repentance have you shown since your tremendous crime? You have inflicted wounds right hard to heal; what salve have you applied?" "Yours" said the emperor "is the duty alike of pointing out and of mixing the salve.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:49
verses.text: It is for me to receive what is given me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:50
verses.text: Then said the divine Ambrosius "You let your passion minister justice, your passion not your reason gives judgment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:51
verses.text: Put forth therefore an edict which shall make the sentence of your passion null and void; let the sentences which have been published inflicting death or confiscation be suspended for thirty days awaiting the judgment of reason.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:52
verses.text: When the days shall have elapsed let them that wrote the sentences exhibit their orders, and then, and not till then, when passion has calmed down, reason acting as sole judge shall examine the sentences and will see whether they be right or wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:53
verses.text: If it find them wrong it will cancel the deeds; if they be righteous it will confirm them, and the interval of time will inflict no wrong on them that have been rightly condemned".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:54
verses.text: This suggestion the emperor accepted and thought it admirable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:55
verses.text: He ordered the edict to be put out forthwith and gave it the authority of his sign manual.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:56
verses.text: On this the divine Ambrosius loosed the bond.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:57
verses.text: Now the very faithful emperor came boldly within the holy temple but did not pray to his Lord standing, or even on his knees, but lying prone upon the ground he uttered David's cry "My soul cleaveth unto the dust, quicken thou me according to thy word".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:58
verses.text: He plucked out his hair; he smote his head; he besprinkled the ground with drops of tears and prayed for pardon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:59
verses.text: When the time came for him to bring his oblations to the holy table, weeping all the while he stood up and approached the sanctuary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:60
verses.text: After making his offering, as he was wont, he remained within at the rail, but once more the great Ambrosius kept not silence and taught him the distinction of places.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:61
verses.text: First he asked him if he wanted anything; and when the emperor said that he was waiting for participation in the divine mysteries, Ambrose sent word to him by the chief deacon and said, "The inner place, sir, is open only to priests; to all the rest it is inaccessible; go out and stand where others stand; purple can make emperors, but not priests".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:62
verses.text: This instruction too the faithful emperor most gladly received, and intimated in reply that it was not from any audacity that he had remained within the rails, but because he had understood that this was the custom at Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:63
verses.text: "I owe thanks," he added, "for being cured too of this error".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:64
verses.text: So both the archbishop and the emperor showed a mighty shining light of virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:65
verses.text: Both to me are admirable; the former for his brave words, the latter for his docility; the archbishop for the warmth of his zeal, and the prince for the purity of his faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:66
verses.text: On his return to Constantinople Theodosius kept within the bounds of piety which he had learnt from the great archbishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:67
verses.text: For when the occasion of a feast brought him once again into the divine temple, after bringing his gifts to the holy table he straightway went out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:68
verses.text: The bishop at that time was Nectarius, and on his asking the emperor what could possibly be the reason of his not remaining within, Theodosius answered with a sigh "I have learnt after great difficulty the differences between an emperor and a priest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:69
verses.text: It is not easy to find a man capable of teaching me the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:70
verses.text: Ambrosius alone deserves the title of bishop".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 17:71
verses.text: So great is the gain of conviction when brought home by a man of bright and shining goodness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:2
verses.text: —Of the Empress Placilla.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:3
verses.text: Yet other opportunities of improvement lay within the emperor's reach, for his wife used constantly to put him in mind of the divine laws in which she had first carefully educated herself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:4
verses.text: In no way exalted by her imperial rank she was rather fired by it with greater longing for divine things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:5
verses.text: The greatness of the good gift given her made her love for Him who gave it all the greater, so she bestowed every kind of attention on the maimed and the mutilated, declining all aid from her household and her guards, herself visiting the houses where the sufferers lodged, and providing every one with what he required.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:6
verses.text: She also went about the guest chambers of the churches and ministered to the wants of the sick, herself handling pots and pans, and tasting broth, now bringing in a dish and breaking bread and offering morsels, and washing out a cup and going through all the other duties which are supposed to be proper to servants and maids.
