verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:7
verses.text: To them who strove to restrain her from doing these things with her own hands she would say, "It befits a sovereign to distribute gold; I, for the sovereign power that has been given me, am giving my own service to the Giver".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:8
verses.text: To her husband, too, she was ever wont to say, "Husband, you ought always to bethink you what you were once and what you have become now; by keeping this constantly in mind you will never grow ungrateful to your benefactor, but will guide in accordance with law the empire bestowed upon you, and thus you will worship Him who gave it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:9
verses.text: By ever using language of this kind, she with fair and wholesome care, as it were, watered the seeds of virtue planted in her husband's heart.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 18:10
verses.text: She died before her husband, and not long after the time of her death events occurred which showed how well her husband loved her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:2
verses.text: —Of the sedition of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:3
verses.text: In consequence of his continual wars the emperor was compelled to impose heavy taxes on the cities of the empire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:4
verses.text: The city of Antioch refused to put up with the new tax, and when the people saw the victims of its exaction subjected to torture and indignity, then, in addition to the usual deeds which a mob is wont to do when it is seizing an opportunity for disorder, they pulled down the bronze statue of the illustrious Placilla, for so was the empress named, and dragged it over a great part of the town.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:5
verses.text: On being informed of these events the emperor, as was to be expected, was indignant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:6
verses.text: He then deprived the city of her privileges, and gave her dignity to her neighbour, with the idea that thus he could inflict on her the greatest indignity, for Antioch from the earliest times had had a rival in Laodicea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:7
verses.text: He further threatened to burn and destroy the town and reduce it to the rank of a village.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:8
verses.text: The magistrates however had arrested some men in the very act, and had put them to death before the tragedy came to the emperor's ears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:9
verses.text: All these orders had been given by the Emperor, but had not been carried out because of the restriction imposed by the edict which had been made by the advice of the great Ambrosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:10
verses.text: On the arrival of the commissioners who brought the emperor's threats, Elebichus, then a military commander, and Caesarius prefect of the palace, styled by the Romans magister officiorum, the whole population shuddered in consternation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:11
verses.text: But the athletes of virtue, dwelling at the foot of the hill, of whom at that time there were many of the best, made many supplications and entreaties to the imperial officers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:12
verses.text: The most holy Macedonius, who was quite unversed in the things of this life, and altogether ignorant of the sacred oracles, living on the tops of the mountains, and night and day offering up pure prayers to the Saviour of all, was not in the least dismayed at the imperial violence, nor at all affected by the power of the commissioners.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:13
verses.text: As they rode into the middle of the town he caught hold of one of them by the cloak and bade both of them dismount.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:14
verses.text: At the sight of a little old man, clad in common rags, they were at first indignant, but some of those who were conducting them informed them of the high character of Macedonius, and then they sprang from their horses, caught hold of his knees, and asked his pardon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:15
verses.text: The old man, urged on by divine wisdom, spoke to them in the following terms: "Say, dear sirs, to the emperor; you are not only an emperor, you are also a man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:16
verses.text: Bethink you, therefore, not only of your sovereignty, but also of your nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:17
verses.text: You are a man, and you reign over your fellow men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:18
verses.text: Now the nature of man is formed after the image and likeness of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:19
verses.text: Do not, therefore, thus savagely and cruelly order the massacre of God's image, for by punishing His image you will anger the Maker.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:20
verses.text: Think how you are acting thus in your wrath for the sake of a brazen image.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:21
verses.text: Now all who are endued with reason know how far a lifeless image is inferior to one alive and gifted with soul and sense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:22
verses.text: Take into account, too, that for one image of bronze we can easily make many more.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:23
verses.text: Even you yourself cannot make one single hair of the slain".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:24
verses.text: After the good men had heard these words they reported them to the emperor, and quenched the flame of his rage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:25
verses.text: Instead of his threats he wrote a defence, and explained the cause of his anger.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:26
verses.text: "It was not right," said he, "because I was in error, that indignity should be inflicted after her death on a woman so worthy of the highest praise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:27
verses.text: They that were aggrieved ought to have armed their anger against me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:28
verses.text: The emperor further added that he was grieved and distressed when he heard that some had been executed by the magistrates.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:29
verses.text: In relating these events I have had a twofold object.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 19:30
verses.text: I did not think it right to leave in oblivion the boldness of the illustrious monk, and I wished to point out the advantage of the edict which was put out by the advice of the great Ambrosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:2
verses.text: —Of the destruction of the temples all over the Empire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:3
verses.text: Now the right faithful emperor diverted his energies to resisting paganism, and published edicts in which he ordered the shrines of the idols to be destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:4
verses.text: Constantine the Great, most worthy of all eulogy, was indeed the first to grace his empire with true religion; and when he saw the world still given over to foolishness he issued a general prohibition against the offering of sacrifices to the idols.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:5
verses.text: He had not, however, destroyed the temples, though he ordered them to be kept shut.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:6
verses.text: His sons followed in their father's footsteps.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:7
verses.text: Julian restored the false faith and rekindled the flame of the ancient fraud.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:8
verses.text: On the accession of Jovian he once more placed an interdict on the worship of idols, and Valentinian the Great governed Europe with like laws.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:9
verses.text: Valens, however, allowed every one else to worship any way they would and to honour their various objects of adoration.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:10
verses.text: Against the champions of the Apostolic decrees alone he persisted in waging war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:11
verses.text: Accordingly during the whole period of his reign the altar fire was lit, libations and sacrifices were offered to idols, public feasts were celebrated in the forum, and votaries initiated in the orgies of Dionysus ran about in goat-skins, mangling hounds in Bacchic frenzy, and generally behaving in such a way as to show the iniquity of their master.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 20:12
verses.text: When the right faithful Theodosius found all these evils he pulled them up by the roots, and consigned them to oblivion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:2
verses.text: —Of Marcellus, bishop of Apamea, and the idols' temples destroyed by him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:3
verses.text: The first of the bishops to put the edict in force and destroy the shrines in the city committed to his care was Marcellus, trusting rather in God than in the hands of a multitude.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:4
verses.text: The occurrence is remarkable, and I shall proceed to narrate it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:5
verses.text: On the death of John, bishop of Apamea, whom I have already mentioned, the divine Marcellus, fervent in spirit, according to the apostolic law, was appointed in his stead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:6
verses.text: Now there had arrived at Apamea the prefect of the East with two tribunes and their troops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:7
verses.text: Fear of the troops kept the people quiet.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:8
verses.text: An attempt was made to destroy the vast and magnificent shrine of Jupiter, but the building was so firm and solid that to break up its closely compacted stones seemed beyond the power of man; for they were huge and well and truly laid, and moreover clamped fast with iron and lead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:9
verses.text: When the divine Marcellus saw that the prefect was afraid to begin the attack, he sent him on to the rest of the towns; while he himself prayed to God to aid him in the work of destruction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:10
verses.text: Next morning there came uninvited to the bishop a man who was no builder, or mason, or artificer of any kind, but only a labourer who carried stones and timber on his back.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:11
verses.text: "Give me," said he, "two workmen's pay; and I promise you I will easily destroy the temple".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:12
verses.text: The holy bishop did as he was asked, and the following was the fellow's contrivance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:13
verses.text: Round the four sides of the temple went a portico united to it, and on which its upper story rested.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:14
verses.text: The columns were of great bulk, commensurate with the temple, each being sixteen cubits in circumference.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:15
verses.text: The quality of the stone was exceptionally hard, and offering great resistance to the masons' tools.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:16
verses.text: In each of these the man made an opening all round, propping up the superstructure with olive timber before he went on to another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:17
verses.text: After he had hollowed out three of the columns, he set fire to the timbers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:18
verses.text: But a black demon appeared and would not suffer the wood to be consumed, as it naturally would be, by the fire, and stayed the force of the flame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:19
verses.text: After the attempt had been made several times, and the plan was proved ineffectual, news of the failure was brought to the bishop, who was taking his noontide sleep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:20
verses.text: Marcellus forthwith hurried to the church, ordered water to be poured into a pail, and placed the water upon the divine altar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:21
verses.text: Then, bending his head to the ground, he besought the loving Lord in no way to give in to the usurped power of the demon, but to lay bare its weakness and exhibit His own strength, lest unbelievers should henceforth find excuse for greater wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:22
verses.text: With these and other like words he made the sign of the cross over the water, and ordered Equitius, one of his deacons, who was armed with faith and enthusiasm, to take the water and sprinkle it in faith, and then apply the flame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:23
verses.text: His orders were obeyed, and the demon, unable to endure the approach of the water, fled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:24
verses.text: Then the fire, affected by its foe the water as though it had been oil, caught the wood, and consumed it in an instant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:25
verses.text: When their support had vanished the columns themselves fell down, and dragged other twelve with them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:26
verses.text: The side of the temple which was connected with the columns was dragged down by the violence of their fall, and carried away with them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:27
verses.text: The crash, which was tremendous, was heard throughout the town, and all ran to see the sight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:28
verses.text: No sooner did the multitude hear of the flight of the hostile demon than they broke out into a hymn of praise to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:29
verses.text: Other shrines were destroyed in like manner by this holy bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:30
verses.text: Though I have many other most admirable doings of this holy man to relate,—for he wrote letters to the victorious martyrs, and received replies from them, and himself won the martyr's crown,—for the present I hesitate to narrate them, lest by over prolixity I weary the patience of those into whose hands my history may fall.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 21:31
verses.text: I will therefore now pass to another subject.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:2
verses.text: —Of Theophilus, bishop of Alexandria, and what happened at the demolition of the idols in that city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:3
verses.text: The illustrious Athanasius was succeeded by the admirable Petrus, Petrus by Timotheus, and Timotheus by Theophilus, a man of sound wisdom and of a lofty courage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:4
verses.text: By him Alexandria was set free from the error of idolatry; for, not content with razing the idols' temples to the ground, he exposed the tricks of the priests to the victims of their wiles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:5
verses.text: For they had constructed statues of bronze and wood hollow within, and fastened the backs of them to the temple walls, leaving in these walls certain invisible openings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:6
verses.text: Then coming up from their secret chambers they got inside the statues, and through them gave any order they liked and the hearers, tricked and cheated, obeyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:7
verses.text: These tricks the wise Theophilus exposed to the people.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:8
verses.text: Moreover he went up into the temple of Serapis, which has been described by some as excelling in size and beauty all the temples in the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:9
verses.text: There he saw a huge image of which the bulk struck beholders with terror, increased by a lying report which got abroad that if any one approached it, there would be a great earthquake, and that all the people would be destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:10
verses.text: The bishop looked on all these tales as the mere drivelling of tipsy old women, and in utter derision of the lifeless monster's enormous size, he told a man who had an axe to give Serapis a good blow with it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:11
verses.text: No sooner had the man struck, than all the folk cried out, for they were afraid of the threatened catastrophe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:12
verses.text: Serapis however, who had received the blow, felt no pain, inasmuch as he was made of wood, and uttered never a word, since he was a lifeless block.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:13
verses.text: His head was cut off, and forthwith out ran multitudes of mice, for the Egyptian god was a dwelling place for mice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:14
verses.text: Serapis was broken into small pieces of which some were committed to the flames, but his head was carried through all the town in sight of his worshippers, who mocked the weakness of him to whom they had bowed the knee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 22:15
verses.text: Thus all over the world the shrines of the idols were destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:2
verses.text: —Of Flavianus bishop of Antioch and of the sedition which arose in the western Church on account of Paulinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:3
verses.text: At Antioch the great Meletius had been succeeded by Flavianus who, together with Diodorus, had undergone great struggles for the salvation of the sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:4
verses.text: Paulinus had indeed desired to receive the bishopric, but he was withstood by the clergy on the ground that it was not right that Meletius at his death should be succeeded by one who did not share his opinions, and that to the care of the flock ought to be advanced he who was conspicuous for many toils, and had run the risk of many perils for the sheeps' sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:5
verses.text: Thus a lasting hostility arose among the Romans and the Egyptians against the East, and the ill feeling was not even destroyed on the death of Paulinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:6
verses.text: After him when Evagrius had occupied his see, hostility was still shewn to the great Flavianus, notwithstanding the fact that the promotion of Evagrius was a violation of the law of the Church, for he had been promoted by Paulinus alone in disregard of many canons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:7
verses.text: For a dying bishop is not permitted to ordain another to take his place, and all the bishops of a province are ordered to be convened; again no ordination of a bishop is permitted to take place without three bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:8
verses.text: Nevertheless they refused to take cognizance of any of these laws, embraced the communion of Evagrius, and filled the ears of the emperor with complaints against Flavianus, so that, being frequently importuned, he summoned him to Constantinople, and ordered him to repair to Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:9
verses.text: Flavianus, however, urged in reply that it was now winter, and promised to obey the command in spring.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:10
verses.text: He then returned home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:11
verses.text: But when the bishops of Rome, not only the admirable Damasus, but also Siricius his successor and Anastasius the successor of Siricius, importuned the emperor more vehemently and represented that, while he put down the rivals against his own authority, he suffered bold rebels against the laws of Christ to maintain their usurped authority, then he sent for him again and tried to force him to undertake the journey to Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:12
verses.text: On this Flavianus in his great wisdom spoke very boldly, and said, "If, sir, there are some who accuse me of being unsound in the faith, or of life and conversation unworthy of the priesthood, I will accept my accusers themselves for judges, and will submit to whatever sentence they may give.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:13
verses.text: But if they are contending about see and primacy I will not contest the point; I will not oppose those who wish to take them; I will give way and resign my bishopric.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:14
verses.text: So, sir, give the episcopal throne of Antioch to whom you will".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:15
verses.text: The emperor admired his manliness and wisdom, and bade him go home again, and tend the church committed to his care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:16
verses.text: After a considerable time had elapsed the emperor arrived at Rome, and once more encountered the charges advanced by the bishops on the ground that he was making no attempt to put down the tyranny of Flavianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:17
verses.text: The emperor ordered them to set forth the nature of the tyranny, saying that he himself was Flavianus and had become his protector.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:18
verses.text: The bishops rejoined that it was impossible for them to dispute with the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:19
verses.text: He then exhorted them in future to join the churches in concord, put an end to the quarrel, and quench the fires of an useless controversy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:20
verses.text: Paulinus, he pointed out, had long since departed this life; Evagrius had been irregularly promoted; the eastern churches accepted Flavianus as their bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:21
verses.text: Not only the east but all Asia, Pontus, and Thrace were united in communion with him, and all Illyricum recognised his authority over the oriental bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:22
verses.text: In submission to these counsels the western bishops promised to bring their hostility to a close and to receive the envoys who should be sent them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:23
verses.text: When Flavianus had been informed of this decision he despatched to Rome certain worthy bishops with presbyters and deacons of Antioch, giving the chief authority among them to Acacius bishop of Beroea, who was famous throughout the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:24
verses.text: On the arrival of Acacius and his party at Rome they put an end to the protracted quarrel, and after a war of seventeen years gave peace to the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:25
verses.text: When the Egyptians were informed of the reconciliation they too gave up their opposition, and gladly accepted the agreement which was made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:26
verses.text: At that time Anastasius had been succeeded in the primacy of the Roman Church by Innocent, a man of prudence and ready wit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 23:27
verses.text: Theophilus, whom I have previously mentioned, held the see of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:2
verses.text: —Of the tyranny of Eugenius and the victory won through faith by the Emperor Theodosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:3
verses.text: In this manner the peace of the churches was secured by the most religious emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:4
verses.text: Before the establishment of peace he had heard of the death of Valentinianus and of the usurpation of Eugenius and had marched for Europe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:5
verses.text: At this time there lived in Egypt a man of the name of John, who had embraced the ascetic life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:6
verses.text: Being full of spiritual grace, he foretold many future events to persons who from time to time came to consult him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:7
verses.text: To him the Christ-loving emperor sent, in his anxiety to know whether he ought to make war against the tyrants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:8
verses.text: In the case of the former war he foretold a bloodless victory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:9
verses.text: In that of the second he predicted that the emperor would only win after a great slaughter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:10
verses.text: With this expectation the emperor set out, and, while drawing up his forces, shot down many of his opponents, but lost many of his barbarian allies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:11
verses.text: When his generals represented that the forces on their side were few and recommended him to allow some pause in the campaign, so as to muster an army at the beginning of spring and out-number the enemy, Theodosius refused to listen to their advice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:12
verses.text: "For it is wrong," said he, "to charge the Cross of Salvation with such infirmity, for it is the cross which leads our troops, and attribute such power to the image of Hercules which is at the head of the forces of our foe".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:13
verses.text: Thus in right faith he spoke, though the men left him were few in number and much discouraged.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:14
verses.text: Then when he had found a little oratory, on the top of the hill where his camp was pitched, he spent the whole night in prayer to the God of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:15
verses.text: About cock-crow sleep overcame him, and as he lay upon the ground he thought he saw two men in white raiment riding upon white horses, who bade him be of good cheer, drive away his fear, and at dawn arm and marshal his men for battle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:16
verses.text: "For," said they, "we have been sent to fight for you," and one said, "I am John the evangelist," and the other, "I am Philip the apostle".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:17
verses.text: After he had seen this vision the emperor ceased not his supplication, but pursued it with still greater eagerness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:18
verses.text: The vision was also seen by a soldier in the ranks who reported it to his centurion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:19
verses.text: The centurion brought him to the tribune, and the tribune to the general.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:20
verses.text: The general supposed that he was relating something new, and reported the story to the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:21
verses.text: Then said Theodosius, "Not for my sake has this vision been seen by this man, for I have put my trust in them that promised me the victory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:22
verses.text: But that none may have supposed me to have invented this vision, because of my eagerness for the battle, the protector of my empire has given the information to this man too, that he may bear witness to the truth of what I say when I tell you that first to me did our Lord vouchsafe this vision.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:23
verses.text: Let us then fling aside our fear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:24
verses.text: Let us follow our front rank and our generals.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:25
verses.text: Let none weigh the chance of victory by the number of the men engaged, but let every man bethink him of the power of the leaders".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:26
verses.text: He spoke in similar terms to his men, and after thus inspiring all his host with high hope, led them down from the crest of the hill.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:27
verses.text: The tyrant saw the army coming to attack him from a distance, and then armed his forces and drew them up for battle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:28
verses.text: He himself remained on some elevated ground, and said that the emperor was desirous of death, and was coming into battle because he wished to be released from this present life: so he ordered his generals to bring him alive and in chains.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:29
verses.text: When the forces were drawn up in battle array those of the enemy appeared by far the more numerous, and the tale of the emperor's troops might be easily told.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:30
verses.text: But when both sides had begun to discharge their weapons the front rank proved their promises true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:31
verses.text: A violent wind blew right in the faces of the foe, and diverted their arrows and javelins and spears, so that no missile was of any use to them, and neither trooper nor archer nor spearman was able to inflict any damage upon the emperor's army.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:32
verses.text: Vast clouds of dust, too, were carried into their faces, compelling them to shut their eyes and protect them from attack.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:33
verses.text: The imperial forces on the other hand did not receive the slightest injury from the storm, and vigorously attacked and slew the foe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:34
verses.text: The vanquished then recognised the divine help given to their conquerors, flung away their arms, and begged the emperor for quarter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:35
verses.text: Theodosius then yielded to their entreaty and had compassion on them, and ordered them to bring the tyrant immediately before him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:36
verses.text: Eugenius was ignorant of how the day had gone, and when he saw his men running up the hillock where he sat, all out of breath, and shewing their eagerness by their panting, he took them for messengers of victory, and asked if they had brought Theodosius in chains, as he had ordered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:37
verses.text: "No," said they, "we are not bringing him to you, but we are come to carry you off to him, for so the great Ruler has ordained".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:38
verses.text: Even as they spoke they lifted him from his chariot, put chains upon him, and carried him off thus fettered, and led away the vain boaster of a short hour ago, now a prisoner of war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:39
verses.text: The emperor reminded him of the wrongs he had done Valentinianus, of his usurped authority, and of the wars which he had waged against the rightful emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:40
verses.text: He ridiculed also the figure of Hercules and the foolish confidence it had inspired and at last pronounced the sentence of right and lawful punishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 24:41
verses.text: Such was Theodosius in peace and in war, ever asking and never refused the help of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 25:2
verses.text: —Of the death of the Emperor Theodosius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 25:3
verses.text: After this victory Theodosius fell sick and divided his empire between his sons, assigning to the elder the sovereignty which he had wielded himself and to the younger the throne of Europe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 25:4
verses.text: He charged both to hold fast to the true religion, "for by its means," said he, "peace is preserved, war is stopped, foes are routed, trophies are set up and victory is proclaimed".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 25:5
verses.text: After giving this charge to his sons he died, leaving behind him imperishable fame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 25:6
verses.text: His successors in the empire were also inheritors of his piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:2
verses.text: —Of Honorius the emperor and Telemachus the monk.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:3
verses.text: Honorius, who inherited the empire of Europe, put a stop to the gladiatorial combats which had long been held at Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:4
verses.text: The occasion of his doing so arose from the following circumstance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:5
verses.text: A certain man of the name of Telemachus had embraced the ascetic life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:6
verses.text: He had set out from the East and for this reason had repaired to Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:7
verses.text: There, when the abominable spectacle was being exhibited, he went himself into the stadium, and, stepping down into the arena, endeavoured to stop the men who were wielding their weapons against one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:8
verses.text: The spectators of the slaughter were indignant, and inspired by the mad fury of the demon who delights in those bloody deeds, stoned the peacemaker to death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 26:9
verses.text: When the admirable emperor was informed of this he numbered Telemachus in the array of victorious martyrs, and put an end to that impious spectacle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:2
verses.text: —Of the piety of the emperor Arcadius and the ordination of John Chrysostom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:3
verses.text: On the death at Constantinople of Nectarius, bishop of that see, Arcadius, who had succeeded to the Eastern empire, summoned John, the great luminary of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:4
verses.text: He had heard that he was numbered in the ranks of the presbyterate, and now issued orders to the assembled bishops to confer on him divine grace, and appoint him shepherd of that mighty city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:5
verses.text: This fact is alone sufficient to show the emperor's care for divine things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:6
verses.text: At the same time the see of Antioch was held by Flavianus, and that of Laodicea by Elpidius, who had formerly been the comrade of the great Meletius, and had received the impress of his life and conversation more plainly than wax takes the impression of a seal ring.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:7
verses.text: He succeeded the great Pelagius; and the divine Marcellus was followed by the illustrious Agapetus whom I have already described as conspicuous for high ascetic virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:8
verses.text: In the time of the tempest of heresy, of Seleucia ad Taurum, Maximus, the companion of the great John, was bishop, and of Mopsuestia Theodorus, both illustrious teachers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:9
verses.text: Conspicuous, too, in wisdom and character was the holy Acacius, bishop of Beroea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 27:10
verses.text: Leontius, a shining example of many virtues, tended the flock of the Galatians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 28:2
verses.text: —Of John's boldness for God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 28:3
verses.text: When the great John had received the tiller of the Church, he boldly convicted certain wrong doers, made seasonable exhortations to the emperor and empress, and admonished the clergy to live according to the laws laid down.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 28:4
verses.text: Transgressors against these laws he forbade to approach the churches, urging that they who shewed no desire to live the life of true priests ought not to enjoy priestly honour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 28:5
verses.text: He acted with this care for the church not only in Constantinople, but throughout the whole of Thrace, which is divided into six provinces, and likewise of Asia, which is governed by eleven governors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 28:6
verses.text: Pontica too, which has a like number of rulers with Asia, was happily brought by him under the same discipline.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 29:2
verses.text: —Of the idol temples which were destroyed by John in Phoenicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 29:3
verses.text: On receiving information that Phoenicia was still suffering from the madness of the demons' rites, John got together certain monks who were fired with divine zeal, armed them with imperial edicts and despatched them against the idols' shrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 29:4
verses.text: The money which was required to pay the craftsmen and their assistants who were engaged in the work of destruction was not taken by John from imperial resources, but he persuaded certain wealthy and faithful women to make liberal contributions, pointing out to them how great would be the blessing their generosity would win.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 29:5
verses.text: Thus the remaining shrines of the demons were utterly destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 30:2
verses.text: —Of the church of the Goths.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 30:3
verses.text: It was perceived by John that the Scythians were involved in the Arian net; he therefore devised counter contrivances and discovered a means of winning them over.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 30:4
verses.text: Appointing presbyters and deacons and readers of the divine oracles who spoke the Scythian tongue, he assigned a church to them, and by their means won many from their error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 30:5
verses.text: He used frequently himself to visit it and preach there, using an interpreter who was skilled in both languages, and he got other good speakers to do the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 30:6
verses.text: This was his constant practice in the city, and many of those who had been deceived he rescued by pointing out to them the truth of the apostolic preaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 31:2
verses.text: —Of his care for the Scythians and his zeal against the Marcionists  On learning that some of the Nomads encamped along the Danube were thirsty for salvation, but had none to bring them the stream, John sought out men who were filled with a love of labour like that which had distinguished the apostles, and gave them charge of the work.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 31:3
verses.text: I have myself seen a letter written by him to Leontius, bishop of Ancyra, in which he described the conversion of the Scythians, and begged that fit men for their instruction might be sent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 31:4
verses.text: On hearing that in our district some men were infected with the plague of Marcion he wrote to the then bishop charging him to drive out the plague, and proffering him the aid of the imperial edicts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 31:5
verses.text: I have said enough to show how, to use the words of the divine apostle, he carried in his heart "the care of all the churches".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 31:6
verses.text: His boldness may also be learnt from other sources.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:2
verses.text: —Of the demand made by Gainas and of John Chrysostom's reply.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:3
verses.text: One Gainas, a Scythian, but still more barbarous in character, and of cruel and violent disposition, was at that time a military commander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:4
verses.text: He had under him many of his own fellow-countrymen, and with them commanded the Roman cavalry and infantry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:5
verses.text: He was an object of terror not only to all the rest but even to the emperor himself, who suspected him of aiming at usurpation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:6
verses.text: He was a participator in the Arian pest, and requested the emperor to grant him the use of one of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:7
verses.text: Arcadius replied that he would see to it and have it done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:8
verses.text: He then sent for the divine John, told him of the request that had been made, reminded him of the power of Gainas, hinted at the usurpation which was being aimed at, and besought him to bridle the anger of the barbarian by this concession.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:9
verses.text: "But," said that noble man, "attempt, sir, no such promise, nor order what is holy to be given to the dogs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:10
verses.text: I will never suffer the worshippers and praisers of the Divine Word to be expelled and their church to be given to them that blaspheme Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:11
verses.text: Have no fear, sir, of that barbarian; call us both, me and him, before you; listen in silence to what is said, and I will both curb his tongue and persuade him not to ask what it is wrong to grant".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:12
verses.text: The emperor was delighted with what Chrysostom said, and on the next day summoned both the bishop and the general before him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:13
verses.text: Gainas began to request the fulfilment of the promise, but the great John said in reply that the emperor, who professed the true religion, had no right to venture on any act against it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:14
verses.text: Gainas rejoined that he also must have a place to pray in.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:15
verses.text: "Why," said the great John, "every church is open to you, and nobody prevents you from praying there when you are so disposed".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:16
verses.text: "But I," said Gainas, "belong to another sect, and I ask to have one church with them, and surely I who undergo so many toils in war for Romans may fairly make such a request".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:17
verses.text: "But," said the bishop, "you have greater rewards for your labours, you are a general; you are vested in the consular robe, and you must consider what you were formerly and what you are now—your indigence in the past and your present prosperity; what kind of raiment you wore before you crossed the Ister, and what you are robed in now.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:18
verses.text: Consider, I say, the littleness of your labours and the greatness of your rewards, and be not unthankful to them who have shewn you honour".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:19
verses.text: With these words the teacher of the world silenced Gainas, and compelled him to stand dumb.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:20
verses.text: In process of time, however, he made known the rebellion which he had long had at heart, gathered his forces in Thrace, and went out ravaging and plundering in very many directions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 32:21
verses.text: At news of this there arose an universal panic among both princes and subjects, and no one was found willing to march against him; no one thought it safe to approach him with an ambassage, for every one suspected his barbarous character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:2
verses.text: —Of the ambassage of Chrysostom to Gainas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:3
verses.text: Then when every one else was passed over because of the universal panic, this great chief was persuaded to undertake the ambassage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:4
verses.text: He took no heed of the dispute which has been related, nor of the ill feeling which it had engendered, and readily set out for Thrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:5
verses.text: No sooner did Gainas hear of the arrival of the envoy than he bethought him of the bold utterance which he had made on behalf of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:6
verses.text: He came eagerly from a great distance to meet him, placed his right hand upon his eyes, and brought his children to his saintly knees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:7
verses.text: So is it the nature of goodness to put even those who are most opposed to it to the blush and vanquish them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:8
verses.text: But envy could not endure the bright rays of his philosophy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 33:9
verses.text: It put in practice its wonted wiles and deprived of his eloquence and his wisdom the imperial city—aye indeed the whole world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:2
verses.text: —Of the events which happened on account of Chrysostom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:3
verses.text: At this part of my history I know not what sentiments to entertain; wishful as I am to relate the wrong inflicted on Chrysostom, I yet regard in other respects the high character of those who wronged him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:4
verses.text: I shall therefore do my best to conceal even their names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:5
verses.text: These persons had different reasons for their hostility, and were unwilling to contemplate his brilliant virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:6
verses.text: They found certain wretches who accused him, and, perceiving the openness of the calumny, held a meeting at a distance from the city and pronounced their sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:7
verses.text: The emperor, who had confidence in the clergy, ordered him to be banished.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:8
verses.text: So Chrysostom, without having heard the charges brought against him, or brought forward his defence, was forced as though convicted on the accusations advanced against him to quit Constantinople, and departed to Hieron at the mouth of the Euxine, for so the naval station is named.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:9
verses.text: In the night there was a great earthquake and the empress was struck with terror.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:10
verses.text: Envoys were accordingly sent at daybreak to the banished bishop beseeching him to return without delay to Constantinople, and avert the peril from the town.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:11
verses.text: After these another party was sent and yet again others after them and the Bosphorus was crowded with the couriers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:12
verses.text: When the faithful people learned what was going on they covered the mouth of the Propontis with their boats, and the whole population lighted up waxen torches and came forth to meet him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:13
verses.text: For the time indeed his banded foes were scattered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:14
verses.text: But after the interval of a few months they endeavoured to enact punishment, not for the forged indictment, but for his taking part in divine service after his deposition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:15
verses.text: The bishop represented that he had not pleaded, that he had not heard the indictment, that he had made no defence, that he had been condemned in his absence, that he had been exiled by the emperor, and by the emperor again recalled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:16
verses.text: Then another Synod met, and his opponents did not ask for a trial, but persuaded the emperor that the sentence was lawful and right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:17
verses.text: Chrysostom was then not merely banished, but relegated to a petty and lonely town in Armenia of the name of Cucusus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:18
verses.text: Even from thence he was removed and deported to Pityus, a place at the extremity of the Euxine and on the marches of the Roman Empire, in the near neighbourhood of the wildest savages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:19
verses.text: But the loving Lord did not suffer the victorious athlete to be carried off to this islet, for when he had reached Comana he was removed to the life that knows nor age nor pain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:20
verses.text: The body that had struggled so bravely was buried by the side of the coffin of the martyred Basiliscus, for so the martyr had ordained in a dream.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:21
verses.text: I think it needless to prolong my narrative by relating how many bishops were expelled from the church on Chrysostom's account, and sent to live in the ends of the earth, or how many ascetic philosophers were involved in the same calamities, and all the more because I think it needful to curtail these hideous details, and to throw a veil over the ill deeds of men of the same faith as our own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:22
verses.text: Punishment however did fall on most of the guilty, and their sufferings were a means of good to the rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:23
verses.text: This great wrong was regarded with special detestation by the bishops of Europe, who separated themselves from communion with the guilty parties.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:24
verses.text: In this action they were joined by all the bishops of Illyria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:25
verses.text: In the East most of the cities shrank from participation in the wrong, but did not make a rent in the body of the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:26
verses.text: On the death of the great teacher of the world, the bishops of the West refused to embrace the communion of the bishops of Egypt, of the East, of the Bosphorus, and in Thrace, until the name of that holy man had been inserted among those of deceased bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 34:27
verses.text: Arsacius his immediate successor they declined to acknowledge, but Atticus the successor of Arsacius, after he had frequently solicited the boon of peace, was after a time received when he had inserted the name in the roll.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:2
verses.text: —Of Alexander, bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:3
verses.text: At this time the see of Alexandria was held by Cyril, brother's son to Theophilus whom he succeeded; at the same time Jerusalem was occupied by John in succession to Cyril whom we have formerly mentioned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:4
verses.text: The Antiochenes were under the care of Alexander whose life and conversation were of a piece with his episcopate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:5
verses.text: Before his consecration he passed his time in ascetic training and in hard bodily exercise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:6
verses.text: He was known as a noble champion, teaching by word and confirming the word by deed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:7
verses.text: His predecessor was Porphyrius who guided that church after Flavianus, and left behind him many memorials of his loving character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:8
verses.text: He was also distinguished by intellectual power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:9
verses.text: The holy Alexander was specially rich in self discipline and philosophy; his life was one of poverty and self denial; his eloquence was copious and his other gifts were innumerable; by his advice and exhortation, the following of the great Eustathius which Paulinus, and after him Evagrius, had not permitted to be restored, was united to the rest of the body, and a festival was celebrated the like of which none had ever seen before.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:10
verses.text: The bishop gathered all the faithful together, both clergy and laity, and marched with them to the assembly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:11
verses.text: The procession was accompanied by musicians; one hymn was sung by all in harmony, and thus he and his company went in procession from the western postern to the great church, filling the whole forum with people, and constituting a stream of thinking living beings like the Orontes in its course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:12
verses.text: When this was seen by the Jews, by the victims of the Arian plague, and by the insignificant remnant of Pagans, they set up a groaning and wailing, and were distressed at seeing the rest of the rivers discharging their waters into the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 35:13
verses.text: By Alexander the name of the great John was first inscribed in the records of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:2
verses.text: —Of the removal of the remains of John and of the faith of Theodosius and his sisters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:3
verses.text: At a later time the actual remains of the great doctor were conveyed to the imperial city, and once again the faithful crowd turning the sea as it were into land by their close packed boats, covered the mouth of the Bosphorus towards the Propontis with their torches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:4
verses.text: The precious possession was brought into Constantinople by the present emperor, who received the name of his grandfather and preserved his piety undefiled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:5
verses.text: After first gazing upon the bier he laid his head against it, and prayed for his parents and for pardon on them who had ignorantly sinned, for his parents had long ago been dead, leaving him an orphan in extreme youth, but the God of his fathers and of his forefathers permitted him not to suffer trial from his orphanhood, but provided for his nurture in piety, protected his empire from the assaults of sedition, and bridled rebellious hearts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:6
verses.text: Ever mindful of these blessings he honours his benefactor with hymns of praise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:7
verses.text: Associated with him in this divine worship are his sisters, who have maintained virginity throughout their lives, thinking the study of the divine oracles the greatest delight, and reckoning that riches beyond robbers' reach are to be found in ministering to the poor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:8
verses.text: The emperor himself was adorned by many graces, and not least by his kindness and clemency, an unruffled calm of soul and a faith as undefiled as it is notorious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:9
verses.text: Of this I will give an undeniable proof.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:10
verses.text: A certain ascetic somewhat rough of temper came to the emperor with a petition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:11
verses.text: He came several times without attaining his object, and at last excommunicated the emperor and left him under his ban.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:12
verses.text: The faithful emperor returned to his palace, and as it was the time for the banquet, and his guests were assembled, he said that he could not partake of the entertainment before the interdict was taken off.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:13
verses.text: On this account he sent the most intimate of his suite to the bishop, beseeching him to order the imposer of the interdict to remove it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:14
verses.text: The bishop replied that an interdict ought not to be accepted from every one, and pronounced it not binding, but the emperor refused to accept this remission until the imposer of it had after much difficulty been discovered, and had restored the communion withdrawn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:15
verses.text: So obedient was he to divine laws.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:16
verses.text: In accordance with the same principles he ordered a complete destruction of the remains of the idolatrous shrines, that our posterity might be saved from the sight of even a trace of the ancient error, this being the motive which he expressed in the edict published on the subject.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:17
verses.text: Of this good seed sown he is ever reaping the fruits, for he has the Lord of all on his side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:18
verses.text: So when Rhoïlas, Prince of the Scythian Nomads, had crossed the Danube with a vast host and was ravaging and plundering Thrace, and was threatening to besiege the imperial city, and summarily seize it and deliver it to destruction, God smote him from on high with thunderbolt and storm, burning up the invader and destroying all his host.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:19
verses.text: A similar providence was shewn, too, in the Persian war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:20
verses.text: The Persians received information that the Romans were occupied elsewhere, and so in violation of the treaty of Peace, marched against their neighbours, who found none to aid them under the attack, because, in reliance on the Peace, the emperor had despatched his generals and his men to other wars.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:21
verses.text: Then the further march of the Persians was stayed by a very violent storm of rain and hail; their horses refused to advance; in twenty days they had not succeeded in advancing as many furlongs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:22
verses.text: Meanwhile the generals returned and mustered their troops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:23
verses.text: In the former war, too, these same Persians, when besieging the emperor's eponymous city, were providentially rendered ridiculous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:24
verses.text: For after Vararanes had beset the aforesaid city for more than thirty days with all his forces, and had brought up many helepoles, and employed innumerable engines, and built up lofty towers outside the wall, resistance was offered, and the assault of the attacking engines repelled, by the bishop Eunomius alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:25
verses.text: Our men had refused to fight against the foe, and were shrinking from bringing aid to the besieged, when the bishop, by opposing himself to them, preserved the city from being taken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:26
verses.text: When one of the barbarian chieftains ventured on his wonted blasphemy, and with words like those of Rabshakeh and Sennacherib, madly threatened to burn the temple of God, the holy bishop could not endure his furious wrath, but himself commanded a balista, which went by the name of the Apostle Thomas, to be set up upon the battlements, and a mighty stone to be adjusted to it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:27
verses.text: Then, in the name of the Lord who had been blasphemed, he gave the word to let go,—down crashed the stone on that impious chief and hit him on his wicked mouth, and crushed in his face, and broke his head in pieces, and sprinkled his brains upon the ground.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:28
verses.text: When the commander of the army who had hoped to take the city saw what was done, he confessed himself beaten and withdrew, and in his alarm made peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 36:29
verses.text: Thus the universal sovereign protects the faithful emperor, for he clearly acknowledges whose slave he is, and performs fitting service to his Master.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:2
verses.text: —Of Theodotus bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:3
verses.text: Theodosius restored the relics of the great luminary of the world to the city which deeply regretted his loss.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:4
verses.text: These events however happened later.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:5
verses.text: Innocent the excellent bishop of Rome was succeeded by Bonifacius, Bonifacius by Zosimus and Zosimus by Caelestinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:6
verses.text: At Jerusalem after the admirable John the charge of the church was committed to Praylius, a man worthy of his name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:7
verses.text: At Antioch after the divine Alexander Theodotus, the pearl of purity, succeeded to the supremacy of the church, a man of conspicuous meekness and of exact regularity of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:8
verses.text: By him the sect of Apollinarius was admitted to fellowship with the rest of the sheep on the earnest request of its members to be united with the flock.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 37:9
verses.text: Many of them however continued marked by their former unsoundness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:2
verses.text: —Of the persecutions in Persia and of them that were martyred there.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:3
verses.text: At this time Isdigirdes, King of the Persians, began to wage war against the churches and the circumstances which caused him so to do were as follows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:4
verses.text: A certain bishop, Abdas by name, adorned with many virtues, was stirred with undue zeal and destroyed a Pyreum, Pyreum being the name given by the Persians to the temples of the fire which they regarded as their God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:5
verses.text: On being informed of this by the Magi Isdigirdes sent for Abdas and first in moderate language complained of what had taken place and ordered him to rebuild the Pyreum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:6
verses.text: This the bishop, in reply, positively refused to do, and thereupon the king threatened to destroy all the churches, and in the end carried out all his threats, for first he gave orders for the execution of that holy man and then commanded the destruction of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:7
verses.text: Now I am of opinion that to destroy the Pyreum was wrong and inexpedient, for not even the divine Apostle, when he came to Athens and saw the city wholly given to idolatry, destroyed any one of the altars which the Athenians honoured, but convicted them of their ignorance by his arguments, and made manifest the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:8
verses.text: But the refusal to rebuild the fallen temple, and the determination to choose death rather than so do, I greatly praise and honour, and count to be a deed worthy of the martyr's crown; for building a shrine in honour of the fire seems to me to be equivalent to adoring it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:9
verses.text: From this beginning arose a tempest which stirred fierce and cruel waves against the nurslings of the true faith, and when thirty years had gone by the agitation still remained kept up by the Magi, as the sea is kept in commotion by the blasts of furious winds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:10
verses.text: Magi is the name given by the Persians to the worshippers of the sun and moon but I have exposed their fabulous system in another treatise and have adduced solutions of their difficulties.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:11
verses.text: On the death of Isdigirdes, Vararanes, his son, inherited at once the kingdom and the war against the faith, and dying in his turn left them both together to his son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:12
verses.text: To relate the various kinds of tortures and cruelties inflicted on the saints is no easy task.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:13
verses.text: In some cases the hands were flayed, in others the back; of others they stripped the heads of skin from brow to beard; others were enveloped in split reeds with the cut part turned inwards and were surrounded with tight bandages from head to foot; then each of the reeds was dragged out by force, and, tearing away the adjacent portions of the skin, caused severe agony; pits were dug and carefully greased in which quantities of mice were put; then they let down the martyrs, bound hand and foot, so as not to be able to protect themselves from the animals, to be food for the mice, and the mice, under stress of hunger, little by little devoured the flesh of the victims, causing them long and terrible suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:14
verses.text: By others sufferings were endured even more terrible than these, invented by the enemy of humanity and the opponent of the truth, but the courage of the martyrs was unbroken, and they hastened unbidden in their eagerness to win that death which ushers men into indestructible life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:15
verses.text: Of these I will cite one or two to serve as examples of the courage of the rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:16
verses.text: Among the noblest of the Persians was one called Hormisdas, by race an Achaemenid and the son of a Prefect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:17
verses.text: On receiving information that he was a Christian the king summoned him and ordered him to abjure God his Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:18
verses.text: He replied that the royal orders were neither right nor reasonable, "for he," so he went on, "who is taught to find no difficulty in spurning and denying the God of all, will haply the more easily despise a king who is a man of mortal nature; and if, sir, he who denies thy sovereignty is deserving of the severest punishment, how much more terrible a chastisement is not due to him who denies the Creator of the world?" The king ought to have admired the wisdom of what was said, but, instead of this, he stripped the noble athlete of his wealth and rank, and ordered him to go clad in nothing save a loin cloth, and drive the camels of the army.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:19
verses.text: After some days had gone by, as he looked out of his chamber, he saw the excellent man scorched by the rays of the sun, and covered with dust, and he bethought him of his father's illustrious rank, and sent for him, and told him to put on a tunic of linen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:20
verses.text: Then thinking the toil he had suffered, and the kindness shewn him, had softened his heart, "Now at least," said he "give over your opposition, and deny the carpenter's son".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:21
verses.text: Full of holy zeal Hormisdas tore the tunic and flung it away saying, "If you think that this will make one give up the true faith, keep your present with your false belief".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:22
verses.text: When the king saw how bold he was he drove him naked from the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:23
verses.text: One Suenes, who owned a thousand slaves, resisted the King, and refused to deny his master.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:24
verses.text: The King therefore asked him which of his slaves was the vilest, and to this slave handed over the ownership of all the rest, and gave him Suenes to be his slave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:25
verses.text: He also gave him in marriage Suenes' wife, supposing that thus he could bend the will of the champion of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:26
verses.text: But he was disappointed, for he had built his house upon the rock.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:27
verses.text: The king also seized and imprisoned a deacon of the name of Benjamin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:28
verses.text: After two years there came an envoy from Rome, to treat of other matters, who, when he was informed of this imprisonment, petitioned the king to release the deacon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:29
verses.text: The king ordered Benjamin to promise that he would not attempt to teach the Christian religion to any of the Magi, and the envoy exhorted Benjamin to obey, but Benjamin, after he heard what the envoy had to say, replied, "It is impossible for me not to impart the light which I have received; for how great a penalty is due for the hiding of our talent is taught in the history of the holy gospels".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:30
verses.text: Up to this time the King had not been informed of this refusal and ordered him to be set free.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:31
verses.text: Benjamin continued as he was wont seeking to catch them that were held down by the darkness of ignorance, and bringing them to the light of knowledge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:32
verses.text: After a year information of his conduct was given to the king, and he was summoned and ordered to deny Him whom he worshipped.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:33
verses.text: He then asked the king "What punishment should be assigned to one who should desert his allegiance and prefer another?" "Death and torture," said the king.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:34
verses.text: "How then" continued the wise deacon "should he be treated who abandons his Maker and Creator, makes a God of one of his fellow slaves, and offers to him the honour due to his Lord?" Then the king was moved with wrath, and had twenty reeds pointed, and driven into the nails of his hands and feet.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:35
verses.text: When he saw that Benjamin took this torture for child's play, he pointed another reed and drove it into his privy part and by working it up and down caused unspeakable agony.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:36
verses.text: After this torture the impious and savage tyrant ordered him to be impaled upon a stout knotted staff, and so the noble sufferer gave up the ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:37
verses.text: Innumerable other similar deeds of violence were committed by these impious men, but we must not be astonished that the Lord of all endures their savagery and impiety, for indeed before the reign of Constantine the Great all the Roman emperors wreaked their wrath on the friends of the truth, and Diocletian, on the day of the Saviour's passion, destroyed the churches throughout the Roman Empire, but after nine years had gone by they rose again in bloom and beauty many times larger and more splendid than before, and he and his iniquity perished.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:38
verses.text: These wars and the victory of the church had been predicted by the Lord, and the event teaches us that war brings us more blessing than peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:39
verses.text: Peace makes us delicate, easy and cowardly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:40
verses.text: War whets our courage and makes us despise this present world as passing away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 38:41
verses.text: But these are observations which we have often made in other writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:2
verses.text: —Of Theodorus, bishop of Mopsuestia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:3
verses.text: When the divine Theodorus was ruling the church of Antioch, Theodorus, bishop of Mopsuestia, a doctor of the whole church and successful combatant against every heretical phalanx, ended this life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:4
verses.text: He had enjoyed the teaching of the great Diodorus, and was the friend and fellow-worker of the holy John, for they both together benefited by the spiritual draughts given by Diodorus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:5
verses.text: Six-and-thirty years he had spent in his bishopric, fighting against the forces of Arius and Eunomius, struggling against the piratical band of Apollinarius, and finding the best pasture for God's sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:6
verses.text: His brother Polychronius was the excellent bishop of Apamea, a man gifted with great eloquence and of illustrious character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:7
verses.text: I shall now make an end of my history, and shall entreat those who meet with it to requite my labour with their prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book V 39:8
verses.text: The narrative now embraces a period of 105 years, beginning from the Arian madness and ending with the death of the admirable Theodorus and Theodotus.

verses.text: I will give a list of the bishops of great cities after the persecution.
